value: Measurement of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is conducted to screen for or monitor prostate cancer, as elevated levels can indicate the presence or progression of the disease, although other non-cancerous conditions can also cause elevated PSA. The test helps in early detection and management of prostate abnormalities.
PSA tests are commonly performed, especially in older men, so cases are frequently encountered in real-world healthcare data.
60 to 70 (The median age reflects the age range when prostate cancer screening typically begins, and benign prostatic hyperplasia becomes more prevalent.)
99% to 100% (PSA tests are specific to prostate health, therefore almost exclusively performed on males.)

70% to 95% (Survival rates vary widely depending on the underlying reason for the PSA test and subsequent diagnosis; if it's due to early-stage prostate cancer detected via screening, survival is typically high, whereas other conditions might affect survival differently.)

Hypertension, Type 2 diabetes mellitus, Hyperlipidemia, Benign prostatic hyperplasia, Coronary artery disease, Osteoarthritis, Obesity, Chronic kidney disease, Depression, Erectile dysfunction (These comorbidities are common in the aging male population, which is also the demographic most often screened for prostate cancer using PSA tests.)

No specific signs or symptoms, Urinary frequency, Nocturia, Hesitancy, Weak urine stream, Urgency, Lower back pain, Hip pain, Hematuria, Erectile dysfunction (Many individuals are asymptomatic, but some may exhibit urinary symptoms related to prostate enlargement or possible prostate cancer symptoms if the elevated PSA is due to malignancy.)

Statins, Antihypertensives, Alpha-blockers, 5-alpha reductase inhibitors, Antiplatelet agents, Antidepressants, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, Oral hypoglycemics, Proton pump inhibitors, Vitamin D supplements (These medications are commonly prescribed for conditions prevalent in older men, who are also the primary group undergoing PSA testing.)

Acetaminophen use refers to the consumption of acetaminophen, a common over-the-counter analgesic and antipyretic, for the relief of pain and fever, often associated with various underlying conditions. The aetiology is driven by individual decisions to self-medicate or follow prescribed regimens for symptomatic relief.
Acetaminophen use is very common, and cases can be readily identified in real-world healthcare data through medication records and patient histories.
40 to 65 (Acetaminophen is used across all age ranges, but more frequently in adults to manage chronic pain or fever.)
45% to 55% (Acetaminophen use is fairly balanced between sexes, though may be slightly higher in females due to a higher prevalence of certain pain conditions.)
65% to 95% (Survival rates are primarily influenced by the underlying conditions prompting acetaminophen use rather than the medication itself.)

Hypertension, Osteoarthritis, Type 2 diabetes mellitus, Ischemic heart disease, Chronic kidney disease, Anxiety, Depression, Gastroesophageal reflux disease, Hyperlipidemia, Obesity (These comorbidities are frequently observed in individuals who use acetaminophen due to the high prevalence of these conditions in the general population, particularly among older adults who are more likely to experience chronic pain.)

Fever, Headache, Muscle pain, Joint pain, Sore throat, Toothache, Back pain, Abdominal pain, General malaise, Insomnia (These signs and symptoms are common reasons individuals use acetaminophen to alleviate discomfort and reduce fever associated with various acute and chronic conditions.)

Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Naproxen, Omeprazole, Simvastatin, Metformin, Lisinopril, Atorvastatin, Levothyroxine, Vitamin D (These medications are commonly co-prescribed to manage comorbid conditions such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and musculoskeletal pain, often alongside acetaminophen for pain relief.)

Morphine use indicates the presence of moderate to severe pain, often stemming from tissue damage, nerve injury, or cancer, leading to its prescription for analgesic purposes. It can also result from recreational drug use leading to physiological and psychological dependence.
Morphine use is relatively common, especially in hospital settings and among patients with chronic pain or cancer, making identification in real-world healthcare data likely.

55 to 75 (Morphine use is more common in older adults due to age-related conditions and increased prevalence of chronic pain, although younger individuals may also be prescribed morphine for severe injuries or postoperative pain.)
45% to 60% (Males are slightly more likely to be prescribed morphine due to a higher prevalence of injuries and certain pain conditions, although the difference is not substantial.)

40% to 85% (Survival heavily depends on the underlying cause of morphine use, with cancer patients potentially having lower survival rates than those using it for chronic pain management or those in remission from addiction.)

Chronic pain, Depression, Anxiety, Opioid use disorder, Insomnia, Gastroesophageal reflux disease, Constipation, Nausea, Vomiting, Headache (These comorbidities frequently co-occur due to the underlying conditions causing pain, the side effects of morphine, or the psychological impact of chronic pain and opioid dependence.)

Constipation, Nausea, Vomiting, Drowsiness, Confusion, Respiratory depression, Miosis, Itching, Euphoria, Sedation (These signs and symptoms are direct physiological effects of morphine on the central nervous system and gastrointestinal tract, varying in intensity based on dosage and individual sensitivity.)

Laxatives, Anti-emetics, Antidepressants, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, Gabapentin, Acetaminophen, Bisacodyl, Docusate, Ondansetron, Senna (These medications are commonly used to manage side effects of morphine, such as constipation and nausea, or to address co-existing conditions like depression and neuropathic pain.)

Warfarin is prescribed to prevent blood clots in individuals with conditions such as atrial fibrillation, deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, or mechanical heart valves, where the underlying etiology involves disruptions in the coagulation cascade or increased risk of thromboembolism.
Warfarin use is relatively common, and cases are readily identifiable in real-world healthcare data due to its widespread use for anticoagulation.
65 to 75 (Individuals typically present in older age groups, reflecting the increased prevalence of conditions requiring anticoagulation in the elderly.)
40% to 60% (The proportion of males and females on warfarin is relatively balanced, reflecting the similar prevalence of conditions requiring anticoagulation in both sexes.)
45% to 75% (Mortality is variable depending on the underlying conditions necessitating warfarin use, with cardiovascular and thromboembolic events significantly impacting long-term survival.)

Atrial fibrillation, Coronary artery disease, Heart failure, Hypertension, Diabetes mellitus, Chronic kidney disease, Peripheral vascular disease, Stroke, Venous thromboembolism, Valvular heart disease (These comorbidities are commonly seen in patients on warfarin as they often contribute to the need for anticoagulation therapy due to increased risk of thromboembolic events.)

Bleeding gums, Nosebleeds, Easy bruising, Heavy menstrual bleeding, Blood in urine, Blood in stool, Petechiae, Prolonged bleeding from cuts, Severe headache, Dizziness (These signs and symptoms are indicative of potential bleeding complications associated with warfarin use, reflecting its anticoagulant effect and the risk of over-anticoagulation.)

Aspirin, Furosemide, Metoprolol, Lisinopril, Digoxin, Amiodarone, Simvastatin, Omeprazole, Levothyroxine, Potassium chloride (These medications are commonly prescribed alongside warfarin to manage underlying cardiovascular conditions, comorbidities, and potential side effects.)
